Executive Summary of the Risk Management Plan

A:  Description of Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Policies

SYSCO Food Services / Cincinnati, recognizes management's responsibility in the protection of it's employees, neighbors, equipment, property and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are first priority. Accident prevention and safety constitute the basics for employee training at this facility.

SYSCO, has established a plant safety program to identify and address hazards in the workplace, evacuation procedures, and accident prevention.

One part of the plant safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management standard (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR Part 68. The facility's Director of Facility Maintenance is responsible for the management of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, terrorist acts, and other types of catastrophic accidents. These programs are designed to prevent accidental injuries, fatalities and illnesses as well as prevention of property damage and off-site consequences.

B:   Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled.

This facility operates a NAICS # 42249 (Grocery and related products) distribution warehouse at  10510 Evendale Drive, Cincinnati, Ohio 45241. A two stage ammonia refrigeration system is employed to maintain temperatures in the storage, holding freezer and shipping areas.

The facility operates a two stage ammonia refrigeration system which provides cooling for t

he entire facility. The amount of anhydrous ammonia contained in this system is in excess of  the threshold quantity 10,000 # , which requires OSHA and EPA compliance. The maximum inventory for this system is 15,000 # . An ammonia release from this system could pose a risk of off-site public impact due to the quantity of inventory, therefore this refrigeration system is subject to the program Level 3 requirements of EPA's RM program.

In the High stage ammonia refrigeration system, ammonia vapor is fed from the HPRU (high pressure re-circulator unit) receiver to the compressors where it is compressed and discharged to the condensing towers, where it is condensed to a high pressure liquid and flows by gravity to the thermosyphon receiver vessel (TSV-1) and through a level control valve station is introduced into the Controlled Pressure Receiver (CPR-1) at a set controlled pressure. Another level control valve station feeds the sub-cooled ammonia to the LPRU, where it is pumped to the evaporators. This liquid absorbs heat from the processes and changes to a vapor and is returned to the LPRU and then to the compressors where the High Stage cycle starts again. Hot Gas from the High stage compressor discharge is used to defrost the low temp evaporators. High pressure liquid ammonia is used to cool the oil in the ammonia compressors thermosyphon oil cooling system. This liquid is supplied directly from the TS-1 vessel. The low stage system employs booster compressors that take ammonia vapor from the LPRU (Low pressure re-circulator Unit) and discharge into the HPRU. The LPRU, is fed sub-cooled liquid ammonia from the HPRU through a level control valve station. These compressors employ liquid injection oil cooling which is supplied by liquid from the CPR vessel.

C:   Summary of Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenario's.

Anhydrous ammonia 
The worst-case release scenario at the facility involves the release of  6,090 #  of ammonia over a ten minute period, due to a fa

ilure of the CPR vessel. The maximum level of the CPR is limited to 90 % (6,090# total) of the vessel capacity during pump-down operations by facility administrative controls based on ANSI / ASHRAE 15-1994 Standards. Under worst case weather conditions, the ammonia vapor could travel 0.40 miles (0.6km) before dispersing to a level where it would no longer pose a hazard to the public, (as outlined in the Risk Management Plan Guidance at the EPRG-2 of 0.14 mg/L). The population impacted by the worst case scenario is 351 residents, two schools, offices, businesses and industrial facilities.

The worst-case scenario is unlikely for the following reasons
7 Industry standards and quality controls were followed in the design of this equipment at its manufacture.
7 Ammonia is not corrosive in this process
7 Pressure safety relief valves limit the operating pressures in the receiver
7 The facility utilizes a preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the vessel
7 The facility has a training program that insures only qualified personnel operate the system
7 The facility requires that all PSM elements as well as company maintenance policies are followed
7 The facility has coordinated its emergency response system with the local fire department, and trains with them at least once a year

The modeled OCA (off-site Consequence Analysis) for this scenario has a radius of less than 0.1 miles (0.16 km).  The population impacted by this scenario is 21 residents, offices, and businesses.
#2)  the second alternate scenario modeled
Based on the failure of a 1-1/4-inch liquid line {hi-pressure} that drains the tower.  This release is 201 pounds per minute of anhydrous ammonia that empties the system of 6,030 pounds.  The OCA equates to a radius 0.1 miles (0.2 km).  The populati

on impact is the same as alternate scenario #1.
#3)  the third alternate scenario modeled
Based on a failure of pumped liquid line, the emergency stop station, and level cutouts.  The liquid line is located on the roof and has a release rate of 400 pounds per minute that empties the entire system charge in 37.5 minutes.  The population impact is approximately 88 residents, offices, and businesses. The alternate release scenarios are unlikely for the following reasons
7 Only trained and authorized personnel have access to the system
7 Sysco has policies to enforce these and all other program requirements including but not limited to the removal of offending employees and contractors from the companies payroll and or contracts
7 The system was designed using standard practices and is maintained by rigid company standards
7 The maintenance program includes a mechanical integrity audit system
7 The maintenance program includes a by shift monitoring of the refrigeration system by fully trained personnel
7 Low level controls, sensors for ammonia monitoring, and available liquid supply to the IC1 and/or LPRU1 would act as active mitigation before the event met the outlines (and modeled) conclusions
7 The piping is routed to avoid impact from traffic sources.  Most piping is located on the roof.
7 The Fork lift operators have been trained and certified by the company, and trained in the locations and operations of the ammonia refrigeration evaporators that are located within their working areas.
7 Industry standards were followed for the manufacture of these containers, and the containers are supplied by a reputable company meeting the guidelines spelled out in the Company's Process Safety Management's Contractors Requirements as well as requirements for chemical suppliers
7 The facility requires that all PSM elements as well as company maintenance policies be followed
7 The facility has trained emergency response personnel and procedures on site to respond quickly to isola

te any potential releases.

7 House keeping and maintenance practices keep area clear of debris and are enforced.


D:  Description of Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program consists of the following elements:

7 Employee Participation:
This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing the program. Employees are also involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that the employees have complete access to the program on company property.  Regularly scheduled meetings are maintained
7 Process Safety Information:
Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in each system.  This written information includes the MSDS program as well as a description of the design of each system.  A library located in the Facility office and available to all employees on company property, is maintained with standards, guidelines, generic information about the chemistry of the systems, and the thermodynamic properties of each process.
7 Process Hazards Analysis:
Formal analysis using the What-If/Checklist technique was conducted at the startup of the system to identify potential hazards.  Each Management of Change and at regularly scheduled intervals Process Hazard Analysis is conducted and recommendations are reviewed.
7 Operating Procedures:
Written, detailed operating procedures have been developed which describe the steps, which are to be followed to safely operate the system.  Each Management of Change and any operation not previously anticipated has a new operating procedure written for the action required.
7 Training:
A scheduled training program has been developed which ensures that all employees that can reasonably be expe

cted to interact with either or both of these systems are trained on all aspects of the systems and on the duties which they should perform.  This is to ensure that both of the process systems are operated and maintained safely.  Only fully trained and Company authorized personnel shall maintain and/or operate these systems.

7 Contractors:
All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia system.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe working practices.  All OSHA related compliance requirements and suggested guidelines are enforced.  Review of all contractors OSHA standards 1910.120, 38, 119 & 134 are reviewed on an individual base for contractors that are involved directly with the ammonia refrigeration system.
7 Pre-Startup Safety Review:
A Pre-Startup safety review is completed for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been completed, and construction has been completed according to design standards and guidelines, before the project is placed into use.
7 Mechanical Integrity:
This element ensures that the systems are built and maintained using excepted preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.  This program is performed on a rigid schedule.  A schedule is maintained in the appropriate files.
7 Hot Work Permit:
These procedures ensure that a signed permit issued by a Company authorized supervisor is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.  This program is supplied by the underwriting Insurance Company for this facility.
7 Management of Change:
      These procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the systems are properly reviewed.  Each element is signed off by the company authorities listed in the MOC documentation.
7 Incident Investigation:
      The procedures ensure that any incident (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented

using an investigation team.  This element involves a standing committee that utilizes hourly employees in this process.
7 Compliance Audit:
There are scheduled procedures to conduct regular audits of the program to ensure that the program is in place and working properly.



E:  Five-year Accident History
No ammonia incidents were identified for the facility in the previous year and a half that this facility has been operating.


F:  Description of the Emergency Response Program

An Emergency response program has been implemented at the facility.  The program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spill and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  The program has been coordinated with the Fire Department.

The emergency response program consists of the following elements:

7 Organization Plan and Responsibilities
7 Communication Procedures
7 Detailed action plans
7 Fire assistance Procedures
7 Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
7 Evacuation Plans
7 Description of outside assistance available
7 Site Re-Entry Procedures
7 Training Program and Drills
7 Risk Management Plan
7 Process Safety Management Plan
